title: Please just give us old Kog back
body:
Riot currently has an obsession with giving every champ an "identity". Generally this comes in the form of a "minigame" or some random thing forced into their kit that makes no sense thematically or balance wise.   A good example being {{champion:114}} with a random aoe heal on an assassin, tank, fighter, adc, hypercarry. (I guess she needed a support ability too)

Considering this, their rework to {{champion:96}}  was all the more perplexing. They basically stripped him down to his W, raising his mana costs in a further attempt to make sure everything is centered around his W. His entire "identity" is that he can attack really fast and it looks kind of funny.

He predictably turned out to be s**t as a result of his terrible numbers.

Well, they finally buffed him, by adjusting his numbers and scalings to allow for more diverse strategies and builds, and.....

Oh, no actually they just buffed his W again.

Now he's strong! Of course, because they moved the passive attack speed bonus from his Q to his W. Now there is zero reason to level anything else. He is even more linear, and he now gets strong a lot faster because he gets a f**kton of stats from leveling one skill. Base attack speed, range, on-hit damage, along with the huge attack speed steroid.

Riot, really, honestly, in all seriousness, just fire your current balance team, or move them to another department at the very least.

People dont like the direction the game is going. They dont like the changes being made to the champs they spent time mastering.  We dont want gimmicks, we dont want snowball mechanics, we dont want raid bosses in the form of "Juggernauts". We want a game that is as close to an even playing field as possible.

And this Kog'maw player wants the real Kog'maw back.

Preaching to the choir here.

What they did to Shen was obscene.

He was Viable (even in Pro Play) as a Top, Jungle and Support... and in Low Elo you could Counter Assassins (LeBlanc, Zed, Akali, Katarina, Talon) and other frustrating Mids (Malzahar) with him in Mid (just start MR).

You could play him as a Pure Tank, as a Hybrid Damage, as a Split Pusher, as a Frontline Engage CC, and as a Utility Support.

He was uber versatile.

Now, he pretty much sucks at everything except 3 Hit Burst Damage.

Shen very much does not suck. He's a lot stronger now than he was and can be more supportive now then he could before due to his W. His E (which was his identity) remained the same, and his Q actually makes him more strategical to play and to play against

His old Q was already multi-layered and Strategic.

You had to choose between 3 Options each time you used it.

Did you use it to Last Hit?  If so, you don't have it to Poke or Sustain.

Use it to Sustain?  Don't have it to Poke or Last Hit.

Use it to Poke?  Don't have it to Last Hit or Sustain.

Then there was using it to Trade or All In... which is similar to Poke but with Follow Up.

That's called Complexity, that's making Decisions.

Now, no matter what... how do you use your Q today?  You use it in a much more Binary fashion now.  You place it to gain more Damage on your 3rd Auto Attack or to have an AoE area to Dodge within... in other words you simply use Q to say "I want to fight HERE".

I find it dumb that a Ninja with Global Presence... freedom... wants to suddenly be tied down to a spot on the map.

So even just looking at the change to his Q, it's already a worse situation than we had previously.  Then add that his Q is a form of BURST Damage.  First off, Shen didn't NEED more Damage... his Sustained Damage was enough.  But secondly... why are we giving Burst Damage to a Shen, to an Engage Tank?

And while I do like the CONCEPT of the Dodge, and the Dodge replaces his weakest Ability in an AP Ratio Shield (the one thing that could have been changed and made sense) they did it all wrong by (1) making it in an AoE Area tied to another Ability and (2) having it affect his Allies.

Also, you have 0 Ranked Games as Shen in Season 6... so what exactly is your experience on Shen?  You have 0 Ranked Games on Shen in Season 5 as well, so not sure how you are able to compare Season 5 Shen to Season 6 Shen, unless you're just spewing something you've read from somewhere.  I'm speaking from Personal Experience on a Champ that is (well, was) my Main.  I'm tying into that the current Professional scene and how they use (or really, don't use) Shen in comparison to Season V.

You know, I have no pedigree on Shen, nor will I pretend to, but just by looking at a side-by-side comparison of the new iteration of Shen juxtaposed to the old iteration of Shen, my opinion is this: New Shen is better designed, and likely easier to balance as a direct result. His old Q was always problematic in the laning phase because it functioned effectively as free harass on a tank that also allowed you to sustain off hitting the enemy target, which gave you health in addition to your shield and AA damage reduction of your enemies via your taunt - all of which you could use by landing your taunt on 1 enemy. This meant that when he's allowed to be really strong, odds are very high that (outside of competitive play where 2v1 lanes can occur) you don't get to beat him in lane, you only ever get to hope to stalemate with him if he's any good, and in the situation of stalemate, that means you're actually losing because of the global pressure he can exert just by existing with his ult. 

One thing I've learned on the boards is that one person talking about his main can make anyone sound like they have boundless strategic depth, and that perspective from people that aren't mains of that champion is necessary to prevent senseless fawning over the perceived complexity of the champion (I can talk your head off about a lot of the strategic interplay of Fizz, for example, but other people will boil him down to his basest elements while I try to discuss it, and often for good reason). If we're being entirely realistic, outside of Shen's ult, he was a decidedly simple champion. The most important thing that separated a bad Shen and a good Shen were game sense - when to ult, who to ult, and if the ult would be worth any potential cost at wherever you left from. And that kind of macro-decision-making wasn't even unique to Shen. 

As to why they might give him an empowered spot: a common theme among tanks is something called 'zone control.' They gave that to him in an area that exists beyond his E cooldown now. If an enemy auto-attacker is going for an ally, congratulations, you can actually help them while your E is on cooldown instead of hoping the enemy auto-attacker is stupid enough to attack a Shen with no taunt to make you. That's kind of important against someone like Draven or Vayne or Koggy or Yi or Xin Zhao, whose primary damage comes in the form of auto-attacks.

I've never played Shen in ranked, no, but i have played the two different iterations of the Champion and I have enjoyed both. 

Before he wasn't as strategic because he was point and click with his Q and his W was a self shield. Now you have to properly position yourself in order to be the most effective that you can. The concept behind your Q is not to build damage, you even said it, you're an Engage Tank, so you build tank items. His Q simply gives you empowered autos, so if you build straight tank, then you can deal some damage as well and survive it.

Also, the rework given to Shen was not meant to keep him as an Engage tank, it was meant to make him more of a brawler than anything (granted building titanic hydra on him is a little broken) Your W is castable where ever the Blade is, moving it through enemies allows you to deal your max damage during a trade due to the slow caused if they run away.

The Dodge was made the way it was because Shen was being seen in a support role moreso than anything. He didn't have great teamfighting in Season 6 due to his single target damage and sustain. Now he has an AoE dodge that makes him and his team stronger. Now granted, him not having any kind of sustain in lane sucks, but now he has a greater late game impact (in my opinion) . Also, I like that you pulled that I have 0 ranked games with him in either season as if only ranked is available to play. 

I, personally, enjoy the new Shen and find him fun to play, as well as I did the old Shen. Now you just have to be a little bit more strategical with your positioning (not only of you but also your blade) instead of how you should use your Q. But all in all, this is my opinion on the new Shen, I'm not saying at all that you have to like him.

Why was he not a good Team Fighter?  Never in my life heard that leveled at a Shen.

He wasn't there to bring a ton of damage, but to apply Sustained Damage, which he did very well.  On top of that, he allowed his Team some extra Sustain for simply Basic Attacking what ever he Q'd, which could often make the difference in a Sustained Fight.  Then, of course, his Taunt could swing a Fight by either pulling the front line out of the way or diving the back line to set up their deletion.

Seriously, never heard ANYONE from Bronze to Pro ever say that Shen as a Champion was bad at Team Fighting.  Now, some Shen PLAYERS were terrible at it... but the Champion himself was a very useful piece in any Team Fight.

That's part of the problem.  He was already a rather Complete and Versatile Champion.  There was no REASON to mess with him at all, and at worst all they needed to do was either change the Shield Scaling to HP OR remove the Shield for a Dodge Mechanic.

His teamfighting was centered around his sustain and him being able to land a multi man taunt. Now, he has a slow, a dodge and is still able to taunt multiple targets. Again, as I stated, It's my opinion

The point was, his Team Fighting was never bad to begin with.  And it wasn't just centered on him being able to land a Multi Taunt, he could specifically flank to land on the Carry, for instance, with Dive Comps.  Though generally he'd "Peel" the entire front line, letting his team walk right on past them to the back then come back to the guys he has taunted and work them.

Jungle Shen is getting a buff in 6.4 that allows Shadow Dash to affect monsters (except obviously those immune to debuffs / CC)

A few things here.

Okay, so Top Shen has a 6.3% Pick Rate.  What was Shen's Season 5 Pick Rate... at any and all positions?

Secondly, they are going to have to Buff Shadow Dash for Jungle Shen to be viable... he had no issue being viable Pre-Rework.  He didn't need a Buff to Jungle, he just needed Smite and a Machete and off he went to the Jungle (Hint:  It was the Q for Sustain and the Passive for a tad more Damage that allowed this).

And as for his Support in Pro Play... are you SURE it's been played?  I mean, you found the 6.3% for Top no problem... but 'for what ever reason' Support Shen isn't listed?  Could be that he hasn't been played in Season 6 as a Support then, could it not?

Remember, PART of what made him appealing as a Support was the Sustain his ADC could get off his Q.

So now he's a Top... that is going to need a Buff to Jungle effectively and we can't find anything to show he's getting picked as a Support.  So as I said, 2 of his 3 Lanes were destroyed.

The great thing about Old Shen was his Versatility... you could take him all over the Map and it works.  You could put him in so many different roles and it worked.  You could have so many different Builds and they would work.  They stripped that from Shen, and from those that loved maining Shen because of his Versatility.

>What was Shen's Season 5 Pick Rate

According to LeagueofGraphs, his season 5 pickrate was around 3.5 - 5% until august 2015, at which point he varied between 8% and 5% for individual patches until season 6 started.

As for his role rates, I can actually tell you that from memory. In patch 5.18, I remember him being played 91% of the time in toplane (from champion.gg). The rest of the time was pretty much only support (I remember this because I looked at item purchase rates for him because I was trying to learn shen, and jungle items and smite had less than a 2% buy/pick rate on him).

For comparison data, Shen is being played as a top laner 78.9% of the time right now (according to champion.gg). That means that he's being played 21.1% of the time in roles that are not top lane. I would assume jungle and support are the other roles he's doing right now, but that's just because I haven't seen many Shen mids or ADCs yet.
 
I never saw any evidence of him being seriously played as a jungler past around season 2 or so (and even then it was rare), and I can't find any records of him being played as a jungler in professional games anytime recently. That may just be due to my ineptitude at searching for that data, so if you have evidence of that, I'd happily take a look at it.

>he had no issue being viable Pre-Rework. He didn't need a Buff to Jungle,

If you go by play rates and competitive pick rates, yes he did. He wouldn't die to the jungle, but he was absurdly slow and easy to bully, and that made him weak. You could technically do it, but in the same way I could technically jungle with Ashe or that I could technically go mid as Nami. It was generally considered a bad pick, even if you didn't automatically lose by doing it.

I really don't have much more to say about that. Shen jungle was bad. He's better at jungling now than he was back then, just because he isn't so ungodly slow. They're not buffing his jungling now to put it on the level of old Shen's jungling. They're buffing his jungle to let him go back there for the first time in years.
They gave Shen the ability to stop them from kiting him. With proper positioning, if your Q moves through them, then they are slowed, allowing him to catch them. His W requires the AoE, not his Q.

Which is sort of the thing... Tanks in general should be able to be Kited.  He already has a Gap Closer to help negate this in his Taunt, which he already had... so why are we adding MORE ways for a Tank to avoid Kite?

Secondly, his Q moves his Blade... so his W (Dodge) requires the AoE, but his Q has to be moved and the tether hit the Champion to draw the Slow and get that extra Damage.  The tether is centered on the Blade, which is the middle of the Q... so saying his Q doesn't require the AoE is a bit silly, because moving the AoE is half of the Q... it just happens.

So we are right back to a Global Presence being tied down to a Local Tether again.
yea because resourceless ranged harras is so healthy *cough*{{champion:238}} *cough*
